text: Again people are scared and I‚Äôm not trying to invalidate anyone‚Äôs fears here just putting our ‚Äúproblem‚Äù into perspective. We need a government (not reform) to put things right and not just lie through their teeth all the time
author: @lunet1st488

text:
We take nowhere near some other countries in asylum seekers either, we took ~108k in 2024 whereas Germany took 250k, without Syrians alone T√ºrkiye took ~209k which shoots to millions when including Syrians. 

Now we go to the countries that are actually seriously affected
Ethiopia 1.1 million 
Egypt 1.5 million 
Cameroon (while in war) took 426k
Uganda 1.8 million 
DRC 515,800 (while in war/severe violence by gangs) this is where immigration can actually severely affect a countries functionality seeing most of these countries have significant issues

The problem in the uk is not the people claiming asylum, it‚Äôs the incompetence by the government and the lack of houses being built and the backlog of the asylum system due to chronic underfunding. If rich people simply paid more and if the government actually stuck to their promises (building more houses, funding asylum employees etc) we wouldn‚Äôt be in this mess. People claiming to send people fleeing persecution and voilence back to sometimes near certain death just so they can save a few ¬£ in taxes which you could have if the government taxed accordingly properly is horrific and this country is politically so uneducated it‚Äôs worrying. Were 5th in Europe for total refugees/asylum seekers taken, were 17th/44 countries when this is adjusted for population. And globally we take less than 1% of in total refugees/asylum seekers, bordering countries usually take the most.

Does this mean we don‚Äôt have any issues due to asylum seeker amount- no, does this mean the so called effects are over exaggerated- yes. Are people uneducated on asylum laws and are scared and just claim the scapegoat made by politicians for their innadaquacy- yes. We need stronger borders a more funded asylum system, better governance; and maybe use our global power to influence the end of conflicts and actually help post British empire countries rebuild.
author: @lunet1st488
